FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Joysticks

A joystick can be used with the Driver Station program to control the robot. Almost any ‚Äúcontroller‚Äù that can be recognized by Windows can be used as a joystick. Joysticks are accessed using the Ge...

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-13T11:24:40.403Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":367,"readers_count":366,"score":83.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":430036,"topic_slug":"simple-way-to-switch-speeds-mid-match","display_username":"Robert ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/basic-programming/joystick.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Joysticks ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":11}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57952,"username":"thegravitor","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thegravitor/{size}/237066_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":47697,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/simple-way-to-switch-speeds-mid-match/430036/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3163377,"name":"","username":"thegravitor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thegravitor/{size}/237066_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-13T12:18:40.592Z","cooked":"

m_rightStick.getX()*0.5} else {
m_rightStick.getX()},

-m_rightStick.getY()*0.5} else {
-m_rightStick.getY});

Here is a hypothetical for using a button to toggle in and out of a slow drive mode using Command-Based by scaling your joystick inputs.

m_drivetrain.setDefaultCommand(new ArcadeDrive(
    () -> m_controller.getRawAxis(ControlConstants.kDriveAxis),
    () -> m_controller.getRawAxis(ControlConstants.kRotateAxis),
    m_drivetrain
));

Trigger m_slowDrive = new Trigger(()->m_controller.getRawButton(ControlConstants.kSlowMode));
m_slowDrive.toggleOnTrue(new ArcadeDrive(
    () -> m_controller.getRawAxis(ControlConstants.kDriveAxis)*DriveTrainConstants.kSlowScalingFactor,
    () -> m_controller.getRawAxis(ControlConstants.kRotateAxis)*DriveTrainConstants.kSlowScalingFactor,
    m_drivetrain
));

For increased torque to play defense you would need a shifting gearbox.

Only up to a point. Most drivetrains these days are traction limited even at fairly normal ratios and apart from running better wheels , there is no way to gain any additional useful torque.

we do not want the torque part we would like something that can hold a tank drive robot without us spinning around them to keep them at a stop for a little bit and we were told to lower our speed and this would help us with that task

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-13T14:03:53.406Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":198,"readers_count":197,"score":49.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":430036,"topic_slug":"simple-way-to-switch-speeds-mid-match","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":47697,"username":"Rlop","name":"Robert ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlop/{size}/187463_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57952,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/simple-way-to-switch-speeds-mid-match/430036/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3164057,"name":"","username":"MolokaiRobotics","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b9bd4f/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-14T00:56:33.996Z","cooked":"

Jumping on this thread:

We want to slow down our drive in general - here‚Äôs what we have. We know how to slow down our other motors, just not the drive.

public void teleopPeriodic() {

m_myRobot.tankDrive(-m_DriverJoystick.getRawAxis(1), -m_DriverJoystick.getRawAxis(3));

if(m_DriverJoystick.getRawButton(6)){
  m_armMotor.set(0.5);
  m_armMotor2.set(0.5);
} else if(m_DriverJoystick.getRawButton(8)) {
  m_armMotor.set(-0.5);
  m_armMotor2.set(-0.5);
} else {
  m_armMotor.set(0);
  m_armMotor2.set(0);
}

if(m_DriverJoystick.getRawButton(5)){
  m_intakeMotor.set(0.75);
} else if(m_DriverJoystick.getRawButton(7)) {
  m_intakeMotor.set(-0.75);
} else {
  m_intakeMotor.set(0);
}

}

Is the response you are seeing too jittery to control effectively?

If so, you can do a couple of things. One is multiplying your joystick values by a percentage (0.7 for 70% max speed) however this isn‚Äôt ideal because you are taking away possible motor power.

Another option would be using a SlewRateLimiter, which you can google and read the WPILib explanation for. It is going to limit how fast your motors can accelerate

We just want to slow it down since our drivers are pretty new to FRC and we want them to have more control over the robot. We don‚Äôt mind losing a bit of motor power since our bot is quite small and light. What would that look like?

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":20,"updated_at":"2023-03-14T02:34:17.461Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":121,"readers_count":120,"score":34.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":430036,"topic_slug":"simple-way-to-switch-speeds-mid-match","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":35690,"username":"sam.mulvey747","name":"Sam Mulvey","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sam.mulvey747/{size}/197506_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38672,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/simple-way-to-switch-speeds-mid-match/430036/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3164140,"name":"Sam Mulvey","username":"sam.mulvey747","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sam.mulvey747/{size}/197506_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-14T02:36:12.467Z","cooked":"

Replace
m_myRobot.tankDrive(-m_DriverJoystick.getRawAxis(1), -m_DriverJoystick.getRawAxis(3));
with
m_myRobot.tankDrive(-m_DriverJoystick.getRawAxis(1) * 0.7, -m_DriverJoystick.getRawAxis(3) * 0.7);
Or replace 0.7 with whatever maximum percent speed you would like.

This was my team‚Äôs code. I thought the filter really added a lot.

  //this gain is the drive wheel speed gain
  gainTgt = 0.25;      //normal driving
  if (leftBumper) {
     gainTgt = 0.8;       //fast driving
  } else if (rightBumper) {
     gainTgt = 0.1;     //slow driving
  }
  gain = prevGain + (0.025*(gainTgt - prevGain));  //filter
  prevGain = gain;

You can also use @Ether‚Äôs method to make the joystick less sensitive at low speeds (meaning less jerky) while still maintaining full power capability. With the this method, you don‚Äôt even need a switch - and the simple version doesn‚Äôt even need an if statement.

paper: joystick sensitivity (gain) adjustment - CD-Media: Papers - Chief Delphi
